question.para: Why is blocking (or quarantining) of emails when phishing emails detected not always an option?

answer.para: Only the SMTP protocol allows the ⪚ to block mails. The details of the POP and IMAP protocols prevent them from being blocked or quarantined.

question.para: When configuring my ⪚ to mark phishing emails received over IMAP, the subject of the mails changes to [PHISH]... only after I click on the message. Why?

answer.para: Most IMAP clients first fetch summary information about emails (subject, sender) so the end user can see a preview list of messages. Only when the user selects (clicks on) the message is the actual content of the message retrieved from the server. It is then that the ⪚ is able to scan the message. Unfortunately, some email clients do not detect the change in subject and update their preview list.

question.para: Why does the Event Log report the sender as my bank, yet is was fraudulent? Why does it not report the real sender?

answer.para: One of the characteristics of phishing emails is that they use deception to change the apparent sender of an email. Although ⪚ can detect the email as a phishing attempt, there is no way to determine the true sender.
